conclusion: To determine if the two objects have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze the velocity-time graph and use the concept of the slope of the velocity-time graph.
The slope of the velocity-time graph represents the acceleration of the object.
A positive slope indicates positive acceleration (the object's speed is increasing).
A negative slope indicates negative acceleration (the object's speed is decreasing).
At \( t = t_1 \), we need to find the slopes of the lines representing Object A and Object B.
The slope can be calculated as the change in velocity divided by the change in time (\( \text{slope} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \)).
From the graph, at \( t = t_1 \), Object A has a positive slope that is very steep, indicating a large rate of change in velocity.
The exact value of the slope cannot be determined from the graph without numerical values, but visually, it appears steeper than the slope of Object B at \( t_1 \).
At \( t = t_1 \), Object B also has a positive slope, but it is less steep compared to Object A.
The exact value of the slope cannot be determined without numerical values, but visually, it appears less steep than the slope of Object A at \( t_1 \).

premise: Since the slope of Object A at \( t_1 \) is steeper than the slope of Object B at \( t_1 \).
conclusion: The acceleration of Object A is greater than the acceleration of Object B at \( t_1 \).

conclusion: No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \). Object A has a greater acceleration than Object B at \( t_1 \).
